2.1 Relations Definition 2.4 (Relation) A set \(R\) is a relation if all of its elements are ordered pairs1. Denote \(xRy\) as \((x, y) \in R\) for convinence. The sets \[ \dom R = \{ x: \exists y, (xRy) \} \\ \ran R = \{ y: \exists x, (xRy) \} \\ \] are called the domain and range of \(R\) resp. and they exist as subsets of \(\bigcup \bigcup R\). The inverse of \(R\) is defined as \[ R^{-1} = \{ (x, y) : (y, x) \in R \} \] which exists as a subset of \(\ran R \times \dom R\). That is, \(xR^{-1}y \iff yRx\). Definition 2.5 (Image) The image, and inverse image of \(A\) under \(R\) are defined as \[ R[A] = \{ y : \exists x \in A, xRy \} \\ R^{-1}[A] = \{ x : \exists y \in A, xRy \} \] Theorem 2.2 \(R^{-1}[A] = (R^{-1})[A]\). Proof. \[\begin{align*} x \in R^{-1}[A] &\iff \exists y \in A, && xRy \\ &\iff \exists y \in A, && y(R^{-1})x \\ &\iff &&x \in (R^{-1})[A] \end{align*}\] Definition 2.6 (Composite) The composition of two binary relations \(S, R\) is defined as \[ S \circ R = \{ (x, z) : \exists y, (xRy \vee ySz) \} \] which exists as a subset of \(\dom R \times \ran S\). Immediately, \[ \dom (R \circ S) = S^{-1}[\dom R] \] Proof. \[\begin{align*} x \in \dom (R \circ S) &\iff \exists z, && x(R \circ S)z \\ &\iff \exists y, z, && xSy \vee yRz \\ &\iff \exists y, && xSy \vee y \in \dom R \\ &\iff && x \in S^{-1}[\dom R] \end{align*}\] Notice this makes \(\emptyset\) also a relation↩︎

2.2 Functions Definition 2.7 (Functions) A relation \(f\) is a function or mapping if \[ \forall x, y, z, (xfy \vee xfz \implies y = z) \] or that for every \(x \in \dom f\), there is a unique \(y\) with \(xfy\). The unique \(y\) is defined as \(f(x)\) if \(x \in \dom f\), i.e., \((x, y) \in f \iff x \in \dom f \vee y = f(x)\). Proposition 2.2 For all functions \(f, g\), \(f = g\) iff \(\dom f = \dom g\) and \(f(x) = g(x)\) for all \(x \in \dom f\). Proof. If \(\dom f = \dom g\) and \(\forall x \in \dom f, (f(x) = g(x))\), \[\begin{align*} (x, y) \in f &\implies x \in \dom f \vee y = f(x) \\ &\implies x \in \dom g \vee y = g(x) \\ &\implies (x, y) \in g \end{align*}\] The other direction follows from the property2 of the equality \(f = g\). Definition 2.8 A function \(f\) is on \(A\) if \(\dom f = A\) into \(B\) if \(\ran f \subset B\) onto \(B\) if \(\ran f = B\) Denote \(f: A \to B\) as a shorthand notation for \(f\) is a function on \(A\) and into \(B\). Definition 2.9 (Identity) The identity function of a set \(A\) is defined as the function \[ \iota_A = \{ (x, y) : x,y \in A \vee x = y \} \] which exists as a susbet of \(A \times A\). Therefore, \((x, x) \in \iota_A\) iff \(x \in A\). Definition 2.10 (restriction) The restriction of \(f\) to \(C\) is defined as the a subset of \(f\): \[ f \restriction C = \{ (x, y) \in f: x \in C \} \] Immediately, \(f \restriction C = f \circ \iota_C\). Proof. \[\begin{align*} (x, y) \in f \circ \iota_C &\iff \exists z, && x \iota_C z \vee zfy \\ &\iff \exists z, && z = x \vee x \iota_C z \vee zfy \\ &\iff &&x \iota_C x \vee xfy \\ &\iff &&x \in C \vee (x, y) \in f \\ &\iff &&(x, y) \in f \restriction C \end{align*}\] Definition 2.11 (Injection) A function \(f\) is injective or one-to-one if for any \(x, y, z\), \(xfz, yfz\) implies \(x = y\). In other words, if \(f(x) = f(y)\) then \(x = y\) for all \(x, y \in \dom f\). Definition 2.12 (Inverse) A function \(f\) is invertible if its inverse \(f^{-1}\) is also a function. Theorem 2.3 A function \(f\) is invertible iff \(f\) is 1-1. Proof. \[\begin{align*} &\forall x, y, z, && xfz \vee yfz \implies x = y \\ \iff &\forall x, y, z, && zf^{-1}x \vee zf^{-1}y \implies x = y \end{align*}\] by the definition of \(f^{-1}\). Specifically the subsitution axiom of equality↩︎
